Build Identifier: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux i686; en-GB; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20110103 Fedora/3.6.13-1.fc14 Firefox/3.6.13

Here at work, we use google docs to edit some shared documents. However, as the interface is rather slow and bulky, I attempted to copy-paste some often-referenced text to a local text file.

This doesn't work: although the text shows up as selected in google docs, some old selection is pasted into emacs instead.

This is a document which we redacted locally, on which we do own the copyright, so I strongly feel we should be allowed to copy it into a local text file. Why does firefox allow google docs to deprive us of our own intellectual property in such a way? If I wanted to give that kind of control to google, I'd use Chrome... :-)

Reproducible: Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a google docs document
2. Select a bunch of text
3. Attempt to paste it elsewhere
Actual Results:  
Some old selection is pasted instead

Expected Results:  
The selected text from google docs should be pasted

Indeed, I'd prefer to have the data taken from "the monitor" (well, really the browser's memory) rather than having to recontact the server to get it again. comments.raw_text:
In the meantime, I think I've discovered how they are doing it (... or how they might be doing it...):

Defining an onmousedown and an onmouseup handler which returns false effectively disables mouse handling, making copy-paste impossible.

I can understand that some javascript UI's might need to depend on this in order to offer a more "seamless integration", but the user should still have the last word on these matters, and we need a way to (temporarily) disable this, if needed, just like we have now with dom.event.contextmenu.enabled

> WFM - Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2.13)
> Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 ID:20101203075014

> What makes you think Google is blocking it?

I don't think you can try to reproduce this on Windows, this is pretty much an X-Window system specific issue.

This is not about Windows clipboard copy-paste, or even X11 clipboard copy-paste, this is about the X-Window system selection. Windows does not have any equivalent feature.

So far, I am able to select text and paste it in this way in Google Docs in Google Chrome, in Firefox from other sites, but not from Google Docs on Firefox.

Perhaps the problem is not that Docs is disabling copy-paste, but that they are not enabling it, as it may require some additional javascript?

comments.raw_text:
Still happening. Has no one found a way around it?

Load a Google doc in Firefox. Select some text.
Run:
echo primary:; xsel; echo; echo clipboard:; xsel -c; echo
Observe that the selected text is not in either PRIMARY or CLIPBOARD.
Back in Firefox, type Ctrl-C. (Edit->Paste just gives a dialog saying it doesn't work and to use Ctrl-C instead.)
echo primary:; xsel; echo; echo clipboard:; xsel -c; echo
Observe that the selected text is still in neither PRIMARY nor CLIPBOARD.

Seems like it should be possible to use something like noscript or adblock to block onmouseup to make it possible to copy text from a Google doc. Has anybody tried it?
http://forums.mozillazine.org/viewtopic.php?p=12758969 offers several bookmarklets that claim to block the onmouseup but they don't help; I wonder if there's something more going on beyond just onmouseup.

If I use a python-webkit-based browser, selecting works fine even though Google puts up a warning that the browser isn't supported. So using non-firefox browsers for Google Docs might be the best workaround for now.
